summary: Tre (Cuba Gooding Jr.) is sent to live with his father, Furious Styles (Larry Fishburne), in tough South Central Los Angeles. Although his hard-nosed father instills proper values and respect in him, and his devout girlfriend Brandi (Nia Long) teaches him about faith, Tre's friends Doughboy (Ice Cube) and Ricky (Morris Chestnut) don't have the same kind of support and are drawn into the neighborhood's booming drug and gang culture, with increasingly tragic results.

reviews.content: A beautifully written film full of remarkable performances that allows to peek in what life is for millions of people, definitively a must watch.
A lot of feeling, a lot of history, extremely striking. It resembles the movie City of God.in Brazil, the war is against the state; in the united states, managed to pit one against the other.

Classic tale of growing up in the hood. Ice Cube was very good in this film. Great subject matter and the characters had very good chemistry. The storyline was believable and the portrayal of the hardships while trying to do better but being at the wrong place wrong time, was well done. A very well done movie, that everyone should see

This film is very memorable in some of its tragic parts and quick-witted line deliveries, and really helped to popularize films of its type, but I struggled with its pacing at times and had a hard time finishing this film in one sitting. By pacing, I mean that the film dragged at some points, and other than its characters and a few scenes, it's just decent at best.

The Editing and Pacing are perfectly done. Truly a Powerful Story that not only has rich characters but does such a great job exploring the different elements of the world around them and never pretends there is easy answers to the problems at hand. An All Time Classic Film.
The older brother of 'Menace II Society', this movie explores the situation facing many black youths in the country. Powerful and provocative, this very moving film is a classic

Practically perfect in every way

Written from first-hand experience, Boyz N The Hood was an incredible calling card for John Singleton, and it remains his most influential and widely recognised film. It's a fascinating window into South Central LA in the mid-80 and early 90s, when the infamous riots would take place, as well as a searing indictment of gang culture. There's not many big events in the film, with most of the time being spent watching characters chat about things, posture and make wise cracks, but that's actually why the film is so enjoyable. It builds a bond between the characters and the audience, draws you into their lives, and as such you feel something when tragedy occurs. The standout performers are, of course, Cuba Gooding Jnr and Ice Cube, who play very different individuals, with separate goals and aspirations, but has them reuniting when the situation calls for it. Most of the dialogue is profanity filled tirades or insult laden banter, but it also contains a lot of insight into the woes of its characters, ones which many people still face to this day. It's not a black and white story of one side versus the other, but about how a life of gang violence will always lead to disastrous consequences. It's one hell of a debut, and its such a shame that Singleton would never reach such lofty heights in his career again. But if he's remembered for nothing other than this film, that's still a legacy to be proud of.
An absolute must watch film.
Really good movie! Good acting!
A must watch. Stunning performances from the entire cast.

Boyz N the Hood thrives off of its central performances and strong screenplay despite a dated score and a plot that sometimes drags. Fishburne and Gooding are both wonderful as father and son. Singleton adeptly mixes social commentary with timeless themes of adulthood and responsibility.

If only more people took note of the message of this movie...

There's a really important message in this film. And Ice Cube just comes out and says it at the very end, for those who managed not to hear it throughout. The message is that America doesn't seem interested in the violence and poverty in our own country. Ice Cube says he turns on the TV and sees all the reports about violence and conflict all over the world. But nothing about his friend getting killed. And the film touches on gentrification and culturally biased standardized testing and several other important issues of systemic racism. In delivering this message, I think the film does a great job. But just as a piece of art or entertainment, I don't think it does anything special. And maybe that's because it was very original when it was made, and since then many other movies have expanded on it and done some of these themes better. I think the message is still very relevant in 2021. But the film isn't amazing in any area. Every American should still see it at least once though.
I would have liked to see more diversity in the cast.  Especially LGBTQ.

A solidly made coming of age story that deals with school, friends, sexuality, family relationships, inner city violence, and more in South Central Los Angeles in the late Eighties and early Nineties.

This is the kind of movie that will make you laugh, cry, tense and question your attitudes towards others. This film manages to provide you with a mix of sensations and emotions, it will take you to extremes in a few minutes, it has very strong social criticisms and it manages to clearly and truthfully convey the realities and difficulties of young blacks in the early 90s, the plot takes place in south central LA and this is certainly not a fairy tale. The trio of protagonists is extremely charismatic, with excellent subplots and the plot twist will change the lives of the protagonists forever.

One of the most influential depictions of urban life, and particularly of black neighborhoods, ever put to film. The excessive degree of parody of both the subject matter and Boyz n the Hood in particular speak to its quality and the impact that the film has had on popular culture. Substantially more nuanced in its characters than many similar films (looking at you, Spike Lee), and while the plot can hardly claim the same degree of sophistication, that doesn't mean that it doesn't convey emotional impact. (4/5)

Sitting down to watch Boyz ‚ÄòN the Hood right now feels fitting. I appreciate what it has to say about the struggles of the black community and gentrification. In fact, I‚Äôd be lying if I didn‚Äôt say that I was a bit choked up when Laurence Fishburne goes on his rant. I wish there was more of that in the film. Sadly, it felt like the rest of the movie was a fairly by-the-numbers story about young people growing up in a dangerous community with a lot of bad influences. Coming-of-age is already a genre that I don‚Äôt typically enjoy, and adding in the depressing nature of this particular film, I had a tough time with it. Admittedly, I was emotionally invested in the journey of the characters, and I shed a few tears at one point when tragedy struck. Yet I saw it coming. Every beat of this movie felt like something I‚Äôve seen before in other films, so it was extremely predictable. Many of those movies might have been drawing inspiration from this one, but I just happen to be in a place now where this all seemed rote. I guess at this point I‚Äôm looking for a more unique or nuanced approach to these topics, or even films that shine a light on how we can move forward rather than the pessimistic note we are left with here. I can‚Äôt deny that Boyz ‚ÄòN the Hood is a well-made movie, and I imagine if I saw it back in the early 90s when I was a teen it would have struck a chord with me and shifted my worldview in some way. Seeing it now, I‚Äôm simply left wanting something more, and that may be a problem with me and not the movie itself.

I wish I'd watched this before Baby Boy rather than after, as I might've appreciated the latter a bit more. That said, this is a clearly-superior version of the latter, with a far superior cast and a fresh story to tell. The books or films I generally seek out and most appreciate fall into two categories, ones that speak so closely to my experience that I feel the pinnacle of connection with the storyteller responsible, or ones that offer a look into an experience that is most foreign and far removed from my own. Boyz N the Hood definitely fits into the latter category, and while most of us are aware that these unfortunate cases of cyclical violence exist, I always think portraying the circumstances and motivations through stories creates way more empathy than a two minute news clip featuring faceless victims. Singleton does an admirable job here, even with aspects such as sound design, where the constant whir of helicopters and outbursts of gunfire creates a level of tension for me, despite the characters seeming totally unaware, as these sounds have become a standard and unalterable feature of their environment.
One of my favorite movies of the 90s. Great writing and acting by all involved. Really heartfelt. A movie that has something to say.
An amazing glimpse into the lives of inner city youth and the near constant threats of violence. An insanely talented cast makes this a must watch, even being 30 years old.

Boyz N The Hood is one of the best hood movies ever made. I love everything from this movie. The movie has it's emotional and powerful scenes that fit into the daily life in South Central Los Angeles and other communities near Los Angeles. Overall, Boyz N The Hood is the film that is well-received to keep the party going.
Hood classic definitely a must watch it's truly a powerful film.

Singleton's untimely death prompted me to finally watch Boyz n the hood and i'm so glad i did. Singleton directs incredibly as he pin pointedly conveys the struggles of black communities and violence between black people. His character development is really accurate and effective as I found myself caring about all the characters i needed to care about and despise the ones who had problems with the  central community despite them all being involved in similar activities. Laurence Fishburne  especially connected with me as he portrays someone who can make a long lie for themselves despite being around violence all his life. This is a sad, breathtaking, seminal film.
Slice-of life approach with a great cast achieves both authenticity and heartfelt drama.
Rewatched with the passing of John Singleton. What a legend. Incredible film ahead of its time!

Confident, stylish, nuanced, with a unique and pronounced perspective that does not try to parse and make sense of the contradictions that cut through the black experience in America, but knows that something so senseless will always resist efforts to neatly rationalize or ignore it.

A very deep and meaningful depiction of what its like to live in a dangerous neighborhood. We see what good parenting can to to better one persons place in the world and what bad parenting does as well.

Boyz N The Hood

Among many heartfelt sequences, the key in here that binds it all is a father and son's relationship that is portrayed with equal innocence as it was written, which is clearly visible in here. John Singleton's amazing writing and brilliant execution skills brings out more from character's perspective that goes deep into it whilst still playing on surface. Cuba Gooding Jr. is doing some of his best work in here but the real game changer is Lawrence Fishburne as a soothing and resolved father in this convoluted world. Boyz N The Hood takes it lightly in its first half and builds up this character driven feature in its second one before the intensity increases and stakes grows bigger than usual (which is projected smartly) in its stunning final act.
good film really great tension and drama really enjoyed it and is probably the best ice cube film amazing film

When some signs we see are to protect us from ourselves and others. When we see sign of the times growing up, being curious, wanting to know more, seeing the realities to see that there is no sign of where we are headed. When some signs point to where we are headed when we fight. When other signs we see that others see are the influences that others need when raising a single child you need both parents.

When others see signs that others have money to live with a kid to loot. When being in someplaces we see signs of danger to be armed. When what signs we don't see when the grass is not greener on our side then others when we only have artificial grass. When others enjoy the signs of the times of their music, gangs, stealing, crime, and fighting. When other signs we don't see when being a man & boy is coming up, to respect your boys & men. When some signs stick with us when we live with what we don't have when it's our property, father, job, girl, & connection. When signs of the times we can only live with when we try to make do with what we have and don't have. 

When signs of the future we don't see where it will take us when we roll & live out our life with our boys. When other signs of growing up we see new things to see when it's kids & wives. When others show signs of boys before hoes when they lack manners. When other signs we see but ignore when addiction, disfunctional households, and rebelious children run wild on the street when sex, drugs and gangs are what's up. When what others hear no sign of they run. When what signs others follow when it's their faith, their future, their relationships, their money, or their shit they see it's important. When what other things others feel important there is no sign they want to see us when some signs others see we need to get out. When we see signs that money is tight to keep what we see for long and mint when it's covered in plastic. 

When what we see signs of people coming out of some places to another place we see signs they have a bright future going places and others going no place when this is the only place they know. When some signs what others are not into we see their way is outside, when it's drinking, gaming, chilling, and ratting to care. When some signs we all don't see to be tested on it to see that way. When coming of age we see signs of difficulty to take it in stride the best we can. 

When some signs others see when they see all to well what happens in such parts to know. When signs just pop out of no where when new faces start popping, new signs start advertising, new views start fighting. When the times shows signs of decline when its property values, old vs young, what's moving in & out, bigger weapons, more harder drugs, corruption, boys not for boys, and views not for views. 

When what others see all too much in higher places of crime we see signs of us being in the wrong place to hate such places we hate seeing signs of decline. When others see signs of the future when others show us their emotions to know what sign of the times it is in there future. When others show signs of the times when it's their tastes and preferences to see what place they prefer when they see other signs they prefer when it's culture. 

When what signs we see we are headed elsewhere when we see signs of us as no good we see other signs pointing us where to go. When what responsibilities we have here we see its not a sign for us to stay. When we didn't see the sign of us being good all around to see it's too late. When what sign of those prowling from neighbouring hoods in our parts we see it's a sign of trouble. When some signs others see is just plain kids stuff when we rather be with boys elsewhere fighting to see the sign of dead end pull up and kill us. When we see it's a sign of those not being good enough to leave such places to only live by such places. When we see the only sign is violence and crime to throw it all away. When such places that capitalize on us to put us down we see the clear sign all around us when they (Mexico) are responsible for such decline. When we see we have a choice to only see the sign to get out while we still can when we have to think of those counting on us.

When what we see no sign are those responsible to see them and kill them. When we see what such places are like and where it's headed to see the only sign we need to see is exit when we move. When others couldn't see the sign of things to come when they die right after. When being in such places for long seeing all the signs is what others do when we are marked or just passing through there is no sign of peace.
Very clever movie. Classic. Great acting. Showed the tough lives in USA.

Boyz N the Hood 
It's a movie about a group of black boys' struggle growing up in poverty, and drug ridden neighborhood. They started out as young boys growing up in the hood of LA. When trying to get out of the hood and one of the guys brother had got a football scholarship to go to the NFL to get his mother and brother out LA. And he was on his way to the store to get some milk for his baby and some guys out another neighborhood. They're riding around and saw him and his friend walking and pulled up on them in shot and killed (Ricky) the guy how had got the football. Now Ricky brother Dougboy and his friends went out looking for the guys who killed his brother. Now their dreams of getting out of California is over now. He had a son he left behind and his mother and brother now Ricky brother and his friend was mad. And found the guys out eating at a restaurant and shot and killed all the guys that had something to do with his brother murder. And it's showing how the police and Los Angeles, California was doing young black male when they catch them outside after dark. It's violent movie, but it's good.

Will the strong survive? "Boyz N The Hood" is a very deep movie. If you are the type of person to be on your phone while watching a movie, you wont watching this because the movie instantly grabs your attention. A few major characters in the movies is, Ice Cube, Morris Chestnut. The movie came out in 1991. It's a very popular movie, just about everybody I ever met watched it multiple times. Its one of those movies you could watch over and over and never get tired of it. The movie was shot in Los Angeles The setting instantly tells you what type of movie it is. Any movie that's informing can be on the urge of being good & 'Boyz N The Hood' is very informing how things were for a certain type of individuals.

	Cuba Gooding Jr. who play's Tre  moved out his mom's house to live with his father due to the violence going on the neighborhood. He also got into a fight in school which really made his mom come to the conclusion that he had to leave as soon as possible. He moves with his dad and the violence still continues. He ending linking up with old friends he knew from when he use to visit his dad. One thing tre had that they didn't have is a father that was around. Violence goes on throughout the movie. 

	When I first seen Boyz N the hood i was very fascinated. It really opened my eyes and made me realize how crazy life can be. My brother and I watched it when we were ten and eleven. My first impression was, "I have to see this again." The movie is very realistic which is my strongest impression, and it's also very relatable because i grew up in a very dangerous community, I moved neighborhood to neighborhood due to violence and it never stopped until I moved to a different city.

The characters played their roles perfectly and I feel as the ones they picked to play each role were a perfect fit. The movie starts off with violence; usually when a movie starts with violence it ends with violence. Tre's mom didn't think that his father's neighborhood was as bad as the one he lived in before. She wouldn't of moved him there if she knew. He moves in with his Dad and experiences a lot of drama. The simple fact that they show you the main characters when they are young and when they are grown, allows you to develop feelings for them. I wanted the best for each character.
The acting was on the point; you would've thought it was based on a true story because of how good the acting was,  i was very convinced. Ice Cube known came from a rough environment so I feel as for him to play Doe Boy which was the ghetto role was very easy.

	If you want to be informed on how lives were for some African Americans, I suggest you watch this movie. It's not based on a true story, but the things that happens in the movie are very realistic. There are shooting scenes, fighting scenes. Lots of drama goes on in movie it's very impressive and informative. Its one of those movies that will snatch your attention immediately

While I was excited to watch this based on the reviews, actors, content... I was pretty underwhelmed and considering turning it off a couple times, namely because the pacing was very slow, I didn't really connect with the characters, and the message about blacks in america and the ghetto/hood was rather over-handed for my tastes.
The last twenty minutes of this movie make a pretty good revenge film. Too bad about the first ninety minutes though.
Strong acting and a clear message make it a noteworthy film.

While it took a little long for things to finally escalate to what good depictions are it was a good study of the hood at its time. I just felt it was gritty enough compared to more recent portrayals. But it's basically a cult classic and on that note likely one I'll come back to.

N.W.A. Introduced the world to life of a young black male in Los Angeles through music. Boyz showed it. Terrific performances by the entire cast, Ice Cube being a standout seeing how it was first role ever. Yes, he essentially playing himself but his natural charisma and ease in front of the camera proved he was going to be a star. John Singleton has crafted a film that will live on for as long as film does. I have seen this movie more times than I can count. ***SPOILERS!!!*** I cry every time Ricky dies. This is powerful filmmaking.
One of the best hood movies of all time. Not many hood movies today will live up to this one. Still one of the foolproof films I've ever seen.

John Singleton becomes the first African-American and the youngest Oscar nominee for Best Director for making a searingly revolutionary film about growing up in the South-Central Los Angeles neighborhood awash with drugs, violence, poverty.

It doesn't matter how many times you watch it, it's still just as powerful.  Singleton shows off just how skillful he is at storytelling with this amazing debut. The themes of responsibly and the struggle of day to day life are masterfully crafted.
I love these powerful tales of the hardship of California hoods. It's just such a strongly acted and made film.

One of my favorite black gangster movies from the 90's. Really good movie about living in a crime hell hole of Los Angeles. Cuba Gooding is good as the teenager who hates it there. My favorite scene is when one of the kids says, "Ya'll want to see a dead body?" similar to Stand By Me and its in the alley behind them.. Ironic.

This movie should be mandatory to be shown at high schools and even middle schools. This is one of those fundamental movies that young kids need to watch in order to make the right choices in life and follow the right path to enlightenment. 

Awesome movie with some great acting and very insightful stuff. I love how the moments where there was suspense building, the music would complement it so well with the saxophone practically screaming.
Pretty intriguing, after watching some other 90s films based around LA gang violence, BntH is top. Would rewatch. 8.6/10
Excellent film. A good companion/precursor to something like The Wire.
I just saw this for the first time ever. I was born in 1994 and this film feels so original and real I absolutely lost it... 22 year old man weeping to a movie is something else...

After so many years this was an interesting watch, in some respects things may not have moved forward, in others, what seemed so far away from the UK is perhaps a little more real. Cuba goosing jr, never quite seemed suited to this character to me, whilst the rest of the cast were. A nostalgic watch from teen days

"Boyz n the Hood" was nominated for the Academy Awards for "Best Director" making John Singleton the youngest and the first African American director to get that suggestion in history and it was well deserved. This is a film about the fictionalized and poignant summaries of one of America's arduous internal problems - violence, poverty, racism, and drug abuse. This is not demoralized hip hop flick, nor a detached and dehumanized story about ghetto violence, it's a story about maintaining your human qualities growing up without a mother and father in a death zone, where people do not value the lives of others and their own lives slightly more. This is an exemplary directional debut from John Singleton, who managed to create an all time classic.
Just awesome. An amazing acting proformance, with a powerful message about gun violence in culturally impoverished America.

At first I was like this movie is really boring but trust me by the end you'll want to rewatch it. I loved how it wasn't constant blood and death and shooting like some hood movie that seem to be falsely portrayed  although slow it really show the radical and non radical struggles of boys b the hood and trying to be accepted in both upper and lower classes on society. A must watch film.

one of the all time best movies ive ever seen the pasion and truth from this movie focusing on the true reality of the hood.it made me and all my friends laught cry and jump out of our chairs in excitment thats how good it was. and it was ice cube first movie he was ever in you cant diss boys n da hood
Pretty intriguing, after watching some other 80s 90s films based around gang violence, Boyz is top. Would rewatch. 8.6/10

Am i the only one to realise that the story has no sense? I mean, mean protagonist and his closest family and friend have no real reason to stay in the hood. Come on, he has a job, he's good at studying, he has a mother who has a degree and pretty nice apartament... the list is pretty long. Everybody in this movie says how hard and dangerous is to live in this district, yet noone seems to look for a way out, except for Ricky.... who is so stupid that he scratches lottery tickets when some guys are trying to do drive by on him... really? The speech that Furious gives at bilboard is basically saying "Yes, we live in a shitty place, but we wont try to leave it, cause its our shitty place. And besides, its not our fault, it's the white people fault."

Tre's mother says that she is trying to protect him so much, yet she never really does anything that would proove it. Hell, she even meets Furious in a restaurant that is clearly placed in "white" part of city....

I could go on and on. Simply its an "OK" movie, but story is really bad if you think abut it for a minute...

Thought provoking as it reveals a lot of dark truths about the African American communities in South Central L.A.; John Singleton's "Boyz n the Hood" offers us three point of views about growing up in a bad neighborhood. All three main leads did an excellent job in bringing their characters to life. They made the situation believable and hard for us to watch. It tackled several themes including friendship, family, and hard struggles. Can't believe this is the same director who directed "Abduction". Ugh...
Seething with raw masculinist angst. Gunplay from out of no where for no damn good reason. Acting was highly engaging.
Again, Classic Gangsta Movie
Much harder to take seriously after having seen the multitudes of parodies it has had taken off of it, despite its exceedingly dark subject matter. Still a good film though.

An unpretentious portrait of a neighborhood dominated by violence, police abuse and even misogyny, and, while it does have some funny moments, it is a serious, realistic look at a slice of American society at constant odds with limited opportunities and public indifference.
An honest and un-biased look at an American sub-culture boosted by well-acted performances from promising new-comers. An instant classic that ages well with our growing society 25 years later.

A gripping, compelling, star studded drama that will leave you on the edge of your seats begging for more. Director John Singleton has out done himself in what will forever be one of the greatest movies ever made.
This is essentially Leone's "Once Upon a Time in America" with an atrocious soundtrack and penchant for anti-violence propaganda.

Only reason why it's not a 4 1/2 to me is Fishbourne's speech on gun and liquor stores. The script is being serious at that point, when the U.S. Government doesn't give out subsidies for shops to set up in the hood, like he would seemingly claim. It is simply Capitalism 101. Go where the money can be made.

The best hood movie ever and I say that boldly Ice Cube, Cuba Gooding, Jr., Morris Chestnut, and Laurence Fishburne all show off their acting skills as this movie goes over the hood in urban America with a compassionate script and story that has so much truth to it. Boyz N The Hood really shows what people don't pay attention to with less exaggeration and more truth.

Unapologetic but accurate portrayal of hood life in L.A.

In the midst of the up and coming west coast "gangsta" rap music phenomenon that was about to sweep across America is popularity, Boyz in the Hood takes you to the place that these songs are written about.  All people from the suburbs know of South Central LA is what NWA and Snoop Dogg have told you about it in their albums.  Sounds kind of grimy and rugged, but in a cool and tough guy sort of way, right?  John Singleton takes that thought that is bobbing in your head and puts a bullet right through it.  This is a devastating look at what most young men in the Los Angeles ghetto have to deal with on a daily basis.  Just walking from a picnic down the street to your house, not even a block away you have to worry about someone driving by and opening up fire on you.  Not just a couple random shots from a handgun, but from an automatic military rifle, because of course you did something for them to cause this behavior, right? Wrong again, they are shooting at you and trying to end your life because you may be wearing the wrong colors or maybe they just don't like your neighborhood for some unknown reason.  What Singleton does with this movie is great, because up until Boyz in the Hood gang violence was glorified in music.  There is no glorification in this movie at all.  If you come away from watching this movie thinking it is cool to be "hood" or live in the "ghetto" you have to immediately have your head examined, because you have lost your mind.  A harrowing look at not only how violence and gangs have an effect on the people involved in this criminal activity, but also how it effects the people around them, their family and friends.  We get a unique look from all perspectives in this movie.  From the mother and father to the gangbanger and the do good star football player athlete and they are all stuck in the hell they are forced to call home.  There is a very poignant scene at the end of this movie where Dough Boy played by Ice Cube just kind of shakes his head and realizes people get killed every single day in their area and no one will ever hear about it or even know about it.  He is not mad at this realization, he has accepted this fact and has come to terms with it.  Which is sad in its own right.
an amazing movie full of heart drama and tragedy
Urban drama about the life of a teen growing up in modern day Compton. It's got some moments but it's doesn't push the envelope enough to be anything special.
kick-ass debut feature from the gr8 John Singleton

A wonderful movie. One of the greatest movies I have ever seen.
Brilliant performances, great emotional impact, and thoroughly entertaining!  "Boyz N The Hood" definitely deserves to be called a masterpiece!  A+

One of the most sadly underrated films of the 90's, Boyz n the Hood succeeds as a rich, compelling coming of age story, a chilling urban crime drama, a heart-wrenching tragedy and an eye-opening encyclopedia of social and ethical problems in America's black communities. Featuring engrossing performances and brilliantly complex characters, this film displays a level of confidence, thematic maturity and depth that, for a directorial debut, is simply astounding.

Boyz n the hood is a great movie with brilliant acting and fantastic directing. It's really well ending and has a heartbreaking ending. It's a very important film that everyone should see but it is a very papergirl and emotional movie. A
John Singleton's coming-of-age masterpiece is impeccable, eye-opening, and perfectly set against its hoodlife backdrop.
The greatest hood movie ever!
Boyz N the Hood is a great film that is still just as relevant today as it was the day it was made.  Highly recommended.
A gripping tale about South Central L.A.

Boyz n the Hood excels as a coming of age film that's unlike any other of its kind. Where most characters in such pictures learn more about themselves, those in Boyz n the Hood struggle to figure out where they are and why their environment is so conducive to the violence and hopelessness that's squeezed all but the literal life out of them, and even then, the violence takes its fair share of that, too. They must learn the whys of where they live before they can focus on the hows of improving their own lives, but as every day goes by a little bit of them is killed off as opportunities and hopes and dreams pass them by. This is a challenging film to watch and one that's even more difficult to understand. It's a rewarding but also a punishing experience all at once, a film that transcends its place and time and people as a serious and unflinching look at a slice of life few ever know.
Worth every star and stands the test of time.

Heartfelt, honest, and quite a thrill. It's scary because, even the portrayal can't really capture on what really happens in the hood or in troubled neighborhoods. The acting was so precise and laid back. Two thumbs up.

As realistic and hard-hitting today as it was when it was released, this is a savagely honest film that truly immerses the viewer into its ostensibly urban perspective. If you aren't persuaded by its coming-of-age angle, then you might be persuaded by the magnificent performances from the film's characters. I'll admit that it is sometimes hard for me to immerse myself into the film's particular setting, but I find that this film is very realistic. I trait I tend to notice about this film is that it's very careful about glamorizing gang violence, and this approach allows for an unadulterated portrait of the film's characters, which are all well-played, and coupled with a solid script, this makes for a highly meritorious work of drama. The film also carries a certain atmosphere, bolstered by its well-polished production values, which give it a kind of timeless quality, which is especially important considering that the issues dealt with in the film are still around today. This is certainly a very thought-provoking film, and a highly immersive one, and for that reason, it is still quite relevant today. Relevant or no, it was a great film, and one of the best the 1990's has to offer.
A perfect interpretation of what life can be like

This movie is almost perfect.  A fantastic cast does a great job portraying what life was like for black youths in the urban slums of the 1990s, and the fact that they all have good and bad sides to them make them more relatable and easy to see as real people (and not just characters).  You really feel for all of them at one point or another, and though the script does feature some misses (such as a crazy black cop whose more of a caricature of a corrupt police officer than a real person) most of it is dead on and you get the sense that director John Singleton was writing about something he lived personally, not just heard about.  Cuba Gooding Jr., Lawrence Fishburne, and Ice Cube are all at the top of their game and their performances combined with a great script make this one a definite must watch.
Chess king by the food court
So depressing but so amazing!

A brutal and powerful cinematic work. The no-nonsense realism of a violent social environment will leave you shocked. The people are haunted by a faceless enemy, the vicious circle of hatred and vengeance. Nobody finds the way out, though all feel time and again that it is not the right course. In such environment an individual grows up, being torn between conflicting emotions and opposing values of life. It was a sad but elegant experience, a brilliant piece of work by all means.

It's rare for a film to generate such intense levels of emotional investment as I felt watching Boyz n the Hood's tragic story unfold. It is a thought-provoking, heart-wrenching coming-of-age drama that masterfully balances poignant social commentary with a deep, character-rich plot. Director John Singleton's exceptional cinematography and some incredibly moving performances round out what is surely one of the most resonant and culturally significant films of the '90s. As a directorial debut, it's nothing short of amazing.

Film was sick doe. Now i know what "don't be a menace" was parodying. Just LA gangster hanging out and getting in trouble, real simple but reall effective. Iliked the characters and the story line. Thought it was great!

Fantastic movie. Boyz in the Hood is a powerful, moving, gut-wrenching, and realistic film about the life of those living in South Central. The story feels and develops so realistically it almost seems like it's based on a true story. The performances are incredible from the entire cast, Cube proving early on in his career that he can be an incredible dramatic performer in addition to comedy, Gooding Jr. showing his talents early on, and Fishburne being an incredible moral teacher for the confused youth of the area. Easily in my top 10 of all time.
I forgot how powerful this movie was.  It comes off a little dated but the message is the same.

Boyz n the Hood is a decent movie that tells about the life of three young youths growing up in the ghetto of Los Angeles. It was John Singleton's first film that he wrote and directed and is probably still considered by most as his best especially considering that he isn't exactly prolific. You could even argue that Singleton's work has gotten worse over the years with almost each movie going down in quality with each one.

This movie works on a lot of levels. The acting is really good. This was Ice Cube's first movie and although he is basically playing a version of himself there is no denying that he has talent as an actor. Cuba Gooding Jr, Laurence Fishburne, and Morris Chestnut also do a great job.

I like this movie although there are some weird things in the plot that don't exactly work for me. In all it is a good movie but in some ways it doesn't seem complete for some reason. I really like the characters and the movie's plot is solid although with these characters I think the whole concept would actually work better as a TV show especially with the high standard of where TV is at now. Overall the movie is slightly above average but not quite on the same level as other similar movies such as Colors (1988).

Finally watched this last weekend. It says something about the quality of writing in a film when you can accurately predict the major plot points and yet they still affect you in a surprisingly poignant way. The depth and skillful structure of this film's narrative set it apart from any other slice-of-life drama, urban or otherwise, I have seen. This movie belongs in the American culture anthology next to Harper Lee's To Kill A Mockingbird and Casablanca. If you haven't seen Boyz n the Hood yet, you're doing yourself a disservice!

Very much relevant 23 years after release, Boyz n the Hood is a must see film that provides a somewhat unbiased look into the problems faced (and caused) by the black community in the U.S., at others and at themselves, which is the crux of the film; how they're offing themselves in record numbers.

Led by a young Cuba Gooding, Jr., and relative newcomers Ice Cube and Morris Chestnut, Boyz n the Hood tells the other side of the story that other social commentary films such as Tony Kaye's American History X (1998) did not.
Compelling direction with an imperative, concise social narrative.
Life,love and death in afroamerican microworld of Los Angeles.Remarkables roles;particularly Cuba Gooding when he had talent.
A heartbreaking, exceptionally acted look at violence in America. Thoughtful, current, and necessary.

A powerful and important film of the 1990's. It does for crime in inner cities what "Do the Right Thing" did for race relations. The performances are the most amazing, primarily from Cuba Gooding Jr. and Ice Cube. John Singleton's films might not have the same stigma than that of Spike Lee's, but they rival in moral correctness. Point being, "Boyz n the Hood" is the MLK to Spike Lee's Malcom X.
"Boyz n the Hood" is a particularly unflinching, unforgettable, though somewhat flawed portrayal of African-American gangs in South Central Los Angeles.

Boyz in the Hood isn't just a showcase for all the horrible things that happen in the hood (√† la Kids). These people felt real. They cared about each other and they weren't all criminals and thugs. They were actual people who I could care about when things went bad. That is the driving force behind this movie.

It is one of the most important films about raw chances and the vicious takes of reality. Boyz N the Hood shows that there is good and bad and no matter what, life has no mercy on either side and the moralistic values of the story is that you have to keep on with your own hard work in spite of struggles. This film is careful not to take the road of sugarcoating the protagonists and Singleton directs this with the core of his heart. This isn't about how blacks are or to depress one with its heavy themes of sexual desire, maturity, drugs, crimes and gangs. It's about how to survive in this dangerous world without losing your humanity and dignity, becoming a respectful person and not turning into cannibalistic animals.

A very grounded human drama that manages to successfully address issues with racism, while also telling a compelling human story with characters who we can connect with and care about. Boys n the Hood isn't for everyone, but it is nonetheless an important movie that should be seen.

10/10
another classic

"Boyz n the Hood" is a powerful and unforgettable drama that is sadly still very relevant today. This movie absorbed me into its uncompromising and realistic world from the moment it started until the very end. I thought the movie has first-rate performances with a script that feels intensely real. The film covers a lot of topics that can spark a variety of discussions and makes a lot of points that I won't be able to just shake off. This is one of those great films where I genuinely have a hard time finding a flaw in it because I was invested in the story all the way through and cared about every character. If you haven't seen this movie, it's a must see that I urge you to take the time to seek out. The film is a true masterpiece from the 90s that is equally heartbreaking and thought-provoking.

"Either they don't know, don't show, or don't care about what's going on in the hood." 

It's a deeply compelling study on the class struggle in South Central Los Angeles, vilified in the mainstream media thanks to the N.W.A.'s (Ice Cube, who appeared in his first movie as Doughboy, gained national prominence and controversy as the primary MC for the N.W.A.) brazen gesture against police brutality: "Fuck The Police". 

This is truly among the greatest movies ever, and I'm glad I had the honor of watching this, albeit twenty-three years too soon.

An amazing chronicle of the lives of a group of friends that grow up together in the Hood of south Central Los angeles. For Tre and his father Furious, it's all about doing the right thing, working hard and make something out of their lives. For Doughboy though it's all about going in and out of jail committing petty crimes and running with his gang doing nothing but drinking and selling rock. Their lives takes different path but their friendship even though tested by time and unfortunate events remain strong. It's the film of a generation and an era. I wish they would make more films like this one and stop producing dumb ass comedies instead. Brain over violence.

Despite its smooth jazz soundtrack that never seems to stop at the appropriate times, Boyz n the Hood is delivers its clean-cut message through passionate performances. To some extent, it should be a necessary American viewing.

One of the most important American films ever made. An absolute masterpiece and a perfect representation of Black suburban life in south central LA. 

Ice Cube and Cuba deliver the greatest performances in the film. The rest of the cast are brilliant as well. 

A must see for anyone who appreciates sheer cinema and incredible film-making.

I won't hesitate to buy the DVD the day I find one in HMV or wherever.

A classic that shows how the life in the hood is a dangerous one. It depicts the story of a group of boys but its message is one of reality. Black on black crime is responsible of more deaths than even some wars. Gang violence and redemption are a domino effect in the ghetto and it shows that life in South Central is rough. My only problem with it was the horrid soundtrack, it could've been much better especially if they threw more Ice Cube & N.W.A. tracks in there. Great hard knock life drama from the early 90's.
this movie a classic

Boyz N the Hood was a movie that I can call a good movie based on most of its quality, but not one that I feel like I'm really meant to relate to that much.  I didn't grow up anywhere near this kind of thing really, but it is a very interesting and informative watch.  I would feel confident in saying that everyone should watch this movie.  Whitey can feel bad for themselves, people that don't live around this kind of thing can get an interesting glimpse into a world they typically prefer to believe doesn't exist, and the people who do live in this world can get some positive messages from a man named Furious that might help them get out of that world.  Stopping that kind of violence is a worthy cause, even if the white man must be blamed for most of it.
Full Review at: http://robertreviewsstuff.wordpress.com/2013/12/09/boyz-n-the-hood-1991/

Where most characters in such pictures learn more about themselves, those in Boyz n the Hood struggle to figure out where they are and why their environment is so conducive to the violence and hopelessness that's squeezed all but the literal life out of them, and even then, the violence takes its fair share of that, too. Whatever you do! Don't watch "Don't Be a Menace" before you watch this movie. It will make you not take it seriously, when really this movie deserves to be taken seriously.

Although its preachy, one sided and follows allot of familiar genre elements, Boyz n the Hood is still a raw, gritty and compellingly made crime drama about inner city life. Its a fascinating,well written and for the most part compelling coming of age movie that's anchored by the believable performances of its leads.
Solidly compelling, though often heavy-handed, and Fishburne's performance is excellent.

Ice Cube failed in Anaconda but I gave him another shot in Boyz 'N he Hood. The gang life is not easy and making a movie about it can be even harder, probably not but I wouldn't know. With the title and summary of the movie I knew this could be one of two movies, one, a violent bloodbath of gang violence with obvious characters and little story, or the exact opposite. Boyz 'N the Hood has really good characters, a deep and meaningful story, and a well developed look in the gang life of California. I don't know how accurate this movie is to the gang life in the 1990s but I felt sympathy for all the characters living in that life and it is hard to believe people actually live like that in real life.
	The story follows the life of Tre, a really intelligent, black, man struggling with the life he lives in. Lawrence Fishburne plays Tre's father and he is an incredible character. I will start this review praising his awesomeness and knowledge of the real world. He is a man who understands the life he lives in and he does not want that for his son. From a very young age he teaches his son how to be a man and how to avoid the life. He is a great role model for his son and brings a lot of depth to the movie. 
There is a scene when he prevents gang violence and goes on a rant about why the hood is the hood. He says something along the lines on the government wants blacks to kill each other. On every corner of the ghetto there is a liquor store and a gun store. That is the true meaning of the movie, or the deeper meaning. Gang violence destroys people's lives and it is pointless. The movie exaggerates how the gangs know it is pointless but they do it because they have to. Ice Cube's character hits on this point too, being the gangster of the movie and the head of his own crew. Its characters like Tre and Ricky which give people hope.
Fishburne and Ice Cube did fantastic in the roles they were given. They went above and beyond and put more than 100% in their performance but Cuba Gooding Jr. plays Tre as an adult and he was underwhelming. I'm not the biggest fan of Cuba Gooding Jr. I don't think he is a great actor but I think he was a good choice for the role. Tre seemed almost unimportant and I don't think it was because of how the story was written, I believe it was because of how he was acted. Tre is different. He doesn't want to live the thug life. He wants to be a success and movie out of the hood. Gooding Jr. didn't act that out so well. His character was boring at times and it took all the way to the end to get any emotion out of him. I liked his character as a kid way better than an adult. That's a huge complement on the child actor, or a slap in the face to Cube Gooding Jr. you decide.
Towards the middle of the movie Ricky has a chance to go to college. Ricky is a great character as well. He isn't so smart but he is good at football. He was another example of people wanting to get out of the hood and his only chance was football. This is the case for a lot of young people trapped in the gang life. Unfortunately, his story was more than predictable and half way through the movie I knew exactly how it was going to end. I wasn't surprised by the ending at all but it didn't take away from the movie as much as I thought it would. The very last scene with Tre and Ice Cube was so emotional and deep it saved the movie for me. It made me able to look past the predictability and enjoy the movie. 
Throughout this review I mention the thug life or the gangster life and I did not expect so much detail of the life in the movie. At one point there is a little girl in a diaper and Tre picks her up before a car hits her. Tre returns her to her mother and all the mother cares about is getting a fix. She didn't care about her child and wanted cocaine instead. "You selling rocks." She says. I know it's a movie but I believed that happens in real life and it made me sick. I like how Tre had a great relationship with his father. I expected him and his father to clash heads and argue, but they didn't. In more ways than one this movie surprised I liked it way more than I thought I would. 
Overall, Boyz 'N the Hood was very emotional, very impactful, very practicable, but very good and I can see myself watching it again and again. I can look past the obvious endgame and enjoy the cinematic experience. Ice Cube gave me a surprising performance while Cuba Gooding Jr. disappointed me. Lawrence Fishburne gave the best performance I have ever seen him in and I expected nothing less. With a title like Boyz 'N the Hood I expected the violent bloodbath. I did not expect the emotional rollercoaster and lovable and relatable characters. This movie surprised me a lot and I'm proud to give it the WillyT Honorable Mention.
in my top 5 hood movies! Menace to society being my favorite
The movie was great and I am a fan of ice cube and his character was very good
One of the important films ever made. Only problem is that every copycat that has come out since then has almost tarnished it's legacy and it's meaning.
John Singleton's debut masterpiece.

I watched this again for the first time in years, it's not how I remembered it but it's still a very good film in which Trey Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr) faces the tough test of making something out of his life when he is surrounded by gang violence, constant murder and drugs. Luckily he has a wise father, Furious Styles (Laurence Fishhburne) to keep him on the straight and narrow. Very good drama with some fine acting, only real criticism is that st points it does feel a bit slow to get to the next major point in the storyline.
only movie that's ever made me cry. timeless and amazing.
A great and powerful film.

Really powerful and moving film.

I could very easily make a song reference here, but I won't, because rap isn't technically music, and plus, if I couldn't already go the rest of my life without hearing another rap song, I'm pretty much spent after this film. Granted, this film's soundtrack isn't too played up, and when it is, it features '90s rap, which is not quite as bad as modern rap, but is still pretty weak, and that is where they get you, because if I am to ever to watch this film again, then that would mean that I would have to sit through its soundtrack again, and I would not mind watching this film... up to a point, of course. Yup, I tell you what, nothing says quality, Oscar-nominated Cannes Film Festival entry quite like "Boyz n the Hood", featuring Ice Cube and Cuba Gooding, Jr., and directed by John Singletone before "2 Fast 2 Furious" and 2011's "Abduction", but make no mistake, if you can get by its title and soundtrack, this film good one. Hey, I joke, but this film's title features a "the", rather than a "da", so clearly we're looking at a truly brilliant filmmaking team, as reflected by its member's going on to make perfectly good decisions in the entertainment business. Hey, Laurence Fishburne's character in this film is named Furious, so maybe John Singleton did "2 Fast 2 Furious" because he thought he was being asked to do a sequel to this film, or at least that's my attempt at finding an excuse for Singleton's "2 Fast 2 Furious", because, you know, it makes Singleton's decision making sound much more sensible. Eh, whatever, I'm just going to go ahead and accept that it was only a matter of time, as Singleton has never been the most subtle of storytellers, as this film will actually tell you. Don't get me wrong, this film is good and all, because as much as I hate to admit it, the hip-hop points in its soundtrack is hardly the biggest of its problems.

I won't go so far as to deem this film's story concept minimalist, because this is a pretty juicy coming-of-age drama that needs time to develop, and takes that time, yet I'm not entirely sure a runtime that stops just short of two hours is entirely necessary, as reflected by the moments in which the film slips into excess material, if not filler, that does little more than run out the clock and slow down momentum, often into repetition. The film is by no means too repetitious, but it does have a tendency to fall into aimless spells that sometimes stick around so long that you kind of get used to them, thus making the eventual shifts in actual plotting focus slightly jarring, and therefore detrimental to resonance that is hurt enough by a bit of undeniable cheesiness. Sure, the film's dramatic hiccups are hardly the cheesiest moments in the film, because even when you disregard the lame '90s neo-soul/R&B and hip hop soundtrack, musical aspects are considerably hurt by a weakly corny score by Stanley Clarke that still carried the stink of pop film score sensibilities of the '80s, and yet, when cheesiness does catch up with the dramatic aspects, they're sometimes in the form of, of all things histrionics. I say, "of all things", because this film is generally quite genuine and realist in its handling of its worthy subject matter, yet there are still those occasions in which the film's dramatic kick feels kind of questionable, or at least comes off as questionable, because if nothing else is mishandled in this film, it is, of course, it's subtlety. There is enough inspiration behind the overdone dramatic touches to compensate for the resonance lost in the fierce wake of subtlety lapses, but there is no fully ignoring the blatant overemphasis on the intense themes and drama that drive this film, which would be more effective if it wasn't so desperate to be effective, telegraphing its depths in a passionately overambitious way that takes you out of the resonance a bit, no matter how striking it may be on the whole. The aforementioned flaws outside of subtlety issues range from barely considerable to fairly light, but subtlety issues can be enough to hold a drama back, and sure enough, no matter how much this film presses on as rewarding, its full potential is ironically all but lost because of John Singleton's being unable to be as controlled as he probably should be in the handling of a worthy tale. In spite of this, as overambitious as this film is, when it fulfills its ambition, at least to a certain degree, it compels, and let me tell you, this film fulfills hits such compelling moments more often than not, as well it should, considering the importance of its subject matter.

The conditions of darkly stereotypical black communities, or rather, "hoods", have been swiftly exacerbating for decades, with the early '90s timeframe in which this film takes place, alone, being all but beyond saving, and that's frustrating, especially when you look within the community and find what lucky few, relatively cleaner blacks there are being challenged, if not threatened, and even influenced by an inhumanly harsh environment that blemishes society as we know it, so the subject matter explored in this film is certainly relevant and important, with worthy that join drama potential within the story concept itself to craft a premise that deserves an inspired execution. As I said, the film is every bit as overambitious as it is inspired, and that cheeses up the interpretation of this worthy story concept, but make no mistake, for every aspect that is too ambitious for its own good, there is an aspect backed by genuinely effective inspiration, even in the writing department, as John Singleton puts together a script that isn't especially outstanding, but is rich enough to do this premise some justice, juggling so many themes - which include life in an unsafe environment, questionable influences, coming of age and bonds between loved ones - that it sometimes gets uneven in its thematic focus, but never to where the thematic depth and dramatic weight of this story aren't fleshed out enough to intrigue and compel. If Singleton accomplishes nothing else as screenwriter, he delivers on characterization that, in spite of subtlety issues and even the occasional histrionic beat, breathes enough life into the essence of this film's characters for them to feel relatable on a human level, and it helps that the portrayals of such well-rounded characters are also graced with human inspiration. As intense as plenty of this film's characters are in a lot of ways, there's only so much for this talented cast to work with, yet there's a certain charisma to everyone, and when more than just charisma is requested, the performers really deliver on dramatic heart whose gradual escalation helps in reinforcing a sense of escalation in the final product's intensity. The impassioned, if often rather underwritten performances throughout the final product help in driving the human weight to this layered and thematically rich study on important social themes, but at the end of the day, it's a certain offscreen performance that really brings Singleton's script to life, and that is, of course, Singleton himself. As director, Singleton doesn't so much unveil shortcomings to be fixed later, as much as he gives you tastes of shortcomings that he's always had, particularly when it comes to subtlety, because if Singleton were more restrained in his meditations upon this subject matter, we would perhaps be looking at a pretty powerful drama, yet as things stand, the commitment to Singleton's storytelling tends to compensate for many of the shortcomings in subtlety through striking imagery and soul that make the heavier moments tense and the more resonant moments all but, if not decidedly piercing. At the very least, Singleton entertains you enough to keep his flaws as a storyteller from throwing you off too much, and when such entertainment value is broken up by dramatic effectiveness, compellingness finds itself firmly secured enough for the final product to take all of its blows and still come out as effective.

Overall, filler often drives storytelling into aimless spells, while the occasional histrionic dramatic beat marks a particularly height in subtlety issues that taint the final product throughout its course and could have crafted an overambitiously underwhelming effort, yet goes fought back enough by the thematically heavy writing, inspired acting and generally entertaining, when not dramatically effective directorial storytelling to do a worthy story concept enough justice for "Boyz n the Hood" to stand as flawed, but ultimately compelling dramatic study on the deplorable then-modern and still-worsening conditions of inner city black communities.

3/5 - Good

where ice cube and i first fell in love
Cuba Gooding Jr. , Lawrence Fishburne and ice cube are very good! Instant classic!
Another amazing ghetto movie with a great story that doesn't exaggerate the truth. Proudly sits next to "Menace 2 Society" in my favorite movie collection.

A great story that really shows you the dark side of LA and all the gangs that still exist. Great acting all around, the cast really moves this story forward and gets you really sucked in. It has it's funny moments with lines and such but the drama really takes over and grabs you. This movie has a very emotion scene that really moves you even keeps you on the edge. The last half hour is fantastic, the whole movie leads up to something you will not believe. It's amazing how this movie shows how it's like to live in these areas and all the hate over nonsense. It's sad people are still like this today even these ruthless gangs. It's a great story of a boy growing up around South Central LA and all the crime going on around him. Boyz n the Hood is a gripping story that will give you a few laughs but in the end a true heart grabbing story and tough drama to watch.
You COULD watch this, but MENACE II SOCIETY is much better.

A Urban Crime Drama film with some interesting charecters.

Boyz n the Hood's depiction of the dog-eat-dog nature of inner city ghettos is pretty much spot on.  Not to mention, Ice Cube who was famous primarily for being in NWA, gives an impressively believable performance, showing that he can be a great musician and a fine actor as well.  Almost everyone performs good to great here though.


One sequence in particular that is truly hard hitting, is the death of Ricky.  The composition of this sequence is nothing short of impressive, with how the sound fades out, aside from the children playing in the background, reflecting the audiences realization of the sudden truth: Ricky has met his demise.  There's also the performances in this part, they're strong throughout the film, but here in particular it's as if they weren't acting; their conviction of shock, grief and sadness at Ricky's death comes across as nothing short of genuine and natural.  Oh yeah, the somber soundtrack adds another layer to this scene.  Not to mention the last thing Doughboy did with Ricky before this scene was beat him up.  All these combined should develop at least a lump in your throat.

It's easy to see why Boyz N the Hood is as influential as it is, and why it spawned a plethora of blaxploitation hood dramas in the 90's onward post its release.  John Singleton, like Quentin Tarantino with Reservoir Dogs, did an impressive job and showed much promising cinematic skill with this debut.
Heartbreakingly honest, "Boyz n the Hood" is a landmark film that sheds light on the hardships of the African American community, exposing tragedy and promoting a message of hope for the future.
